utterances: The Cowboys' season ended in excruciating fashion two weeks ago, when they muffed the snap on a chip shot field goal that would have won them the game.
But Bill Parcells went right back to work right after that.
Did this decision come as a surprise?
Yeah.
You know, the people who know Bill Parcells didn't just call it a surprise.
They called it a shock.
And at this point, you know, there's just a lot of speculation about why this happened.
As you said, he went right back to work.
We don't know what he was doing at work, if he was just miserable as always or plotting his fifth season with the Cowboys.
But today the surprise announcement came.
And, you know, like most NFL head coaches, Bill Parcells is extremely guarded in what he says publicly.

So there was no cheerful press conference where he said Terrell Owens drove me out of the game or that playoff loss you mentioned ripped my heart out or Jerry Jones - the Cowboys' owner - won't give me more money.
He just issued a statement saying Dallas is a great city.
And I'm hopeful that the Cowboys are able to go forward from here.
He said I'm in good health, and I feel lucky to have been able to coach in the NFL.
And you mentioned Terrell Owens, one of the better players in the football league.
Also one of the more distracting players in football.
Yeah.
You know, that - Bill Parcells, I believe, began the job with white hair.
But had he not, his hair would have turned white just with one year under Terrell Owens, known as T.O.
- you know, the shenanigans that he goes through.
He's always seeking the limelight, and usually always gets it.
And it's enough - you know, Bill Parcells is a great coach.
And he hates it when one player is featured like that.
But everyone, you know, loves the soap opera sagas with Terrell Owens and the ranting and raving on the side lines.
And one year of that, who knows if that was enough to drive him out?
As you mentioned, no question Bill Parcells is a great coach.
But he had a mediocre record win four years with the Cowboys, and did not win so much as a single playoff game.
Yeah.
You're right.
And the expectations are so huge in Dallas.
You know, they call the Cowboys America's team.
And when he took this job, the expectations were great.
The expectations were huge that he was going to do to the Cowboys what he did to those other teams that you mentioned.
I mean, he is the only coach in NFL history to take four different teams to the playoffs.
No coach in history in the league has shown such a knack for taking reclamation projects and turning them into winners.
So he comes to the Cowboys.
They had had three straight seasons of five wins and 11 losses.
And he turned them into a winning team.
They had three winning seasons.
But as you mentioned, they only got to the playoffs twice.
They lost both playoff games.
And in Dallas, that doesn't wash.
A record of 34 wins and 32 losses, including the two playoff losses, that's not what the expectations were in Dallas.
Any - I guess nobody's going to know until they get a chance to actually talk to Bill Parcells.
But he's retired before.
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
That's something we should definitely say.
Most recently, when he left the New York Jets in 1999, he said something along the lines of I have coached my last game in football.
Write it down.
Write it on the chalkboard.
Whatever you want to say.
I have coached my last game.
I heard that one of the auditions that you went in to, you took your children, and they were taking too long.
Oh, that was for ""Reno 911.
First of all, it's hard to really say if the Iranians were directly involved in this or not.
You know, it's a mistake to overlook the Houthis' agency here.
Now, if Tehran was indeed behind the attack, I think it is trying to impose a cost on the U.S.
and its allies for inflicting maximum harm on the Iranian economy.
This was the entirely predictable outcome of the Trump administration's maximum pressure strategy.

And the attacks clearly demonstrate that the strategy of bombing and blockading the Yemenis and starving the Iranians into submission is more likely to backfire than to bring the intended policy results.
And so what advice would you give to each side here?
Look.

The reality is that the Iranians have increasingly less to lose as a result of the sanctions that the Trump administration has imposed on them and does seem to have become increasingly less risk-averse.
And I think any retaliation against Iran is more likely than not to prompt an Iranian counterattack that, in turn, risks inflaming the entire region.
So the solution is not to further escalate tensions but to capitalize on the initiative that President Macron of France has put on the table to de-escalate tensions between Tehran and Washington.
That's the only way out.
That's the last and best option for averting a disastrous regional war in the Middle East that would have basically no winners.
Ali Vaez of the International Crisis Group, thank you for speaking with us today.
My pleasure.
Thank you.
I'm Tony Cox, and this is News & Notes.

I'm Niecy Nash, and this is ""Clean House.
The actress and comedian shines when she's working without a script.
She is starring in two TV shows at once, ""Reno 911"" and the home makeover show ""Clean House."" Nash recently sat down with NPR's Tony Cox to talk about her career and how she got into the biz.
Man, like so many other people who do this genre of entertainment, it was birthed out of tragedy.
When I was, I want to say 15 or 16, I saw my mother get shot.
Oh.
And then, maybe the day before my 22nd or 23rd birthday, my brother was killed.
And so, my family had experienced so much tragedy.
And by the time my brother was killed, my mother - who had survived her incident - she was, like, in a horrible depression.
So, she was, like, I'm getting into bed and I'm never getting back up.
And she meant it.
So, I'm coming to her house every day.
And I'm standing at the foot of the bed telling jokes and stories and trying to potluck(ph) and cabbage patch, and you know, trying to work it out.
And eventually, she went from laying down in the bed to sitting up in the bed.
So, I've got my peanuts and my water.
Go on and stand up there and do your rendition of things.
So, one day I go to her house and she's not in the bed.
I'm like, where's my mother?
And I look, and she's, like, we're in here.
I'm like, who is we?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I went across the street and I got the neighbors.
And I told them you was funny, stand up, y'all are going to love this.
I'm, like, what?
(Soundbite of laughter)
So, I'm - I start performing in the living room that was...
No kidding.
How I started.
And then I didn't want to be selfish.
I realized in that moment that comedy was a gift.
And so when I went outside and I said, I'm Niecy Nash and I'm funny, they were, like, you're right.
Get over here.
We will give you a job.
Really.
Now, you know, its one thing to perform for your mama and the neighbors.
